claim: Margaret Sanger was a racist who believed in eugenics. Her goal when founding Planned Parenthood was to eradicate minorities.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: Evidence is conflicting with Margaret Sanger, as she was a progressive who believed in racial integration. She voted for Norman Thomas. She worked with progressive Black people—W.E.B. Du Bois, for example, who, along with Mary McCleod Bethune and Adam Clayton Powell Sr., served on the board of the Negro Project, a network of birth control and maternal health clinics Sanger established in Harlem and the South, etc. However, it does seem that Sanger believed in eugenics and thought people, especially poor people, often had too many kids to care for properly and that too many of those kids were born physically disabled (or, in the language of the day, "feeble-minded"). She did not oppose forced sterilization.
speaker: Abby Johnson
reporting_source: Speech at The Republican National Convention

pregnant women with COVID-19 do not appear to be at increased risk

Pregnant women or recently pregnant women who are  older, overweight, and have pre-existing medical conditions such as hypertension and diabetes seem to have an increased  risk of developing severe COVID-19
Due to changes in their bodies and immune systems, we know that pregnant women can be badly affected by some respiratory infections. It is therefore important that they take precautions to protect themselves against COVID-19, and report possible symptoms (including fever, cough or difficulty in breathing) to their healthcare provider.

So other health factors seem to play a part.

I have marked conflicting evidence because it saves some people in some circumstances.

claim: An Expansion of Mail-in Ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA.

justification: The QA cover a lot of ground in terms of information around voter fraud and mail in ballots, there good probing question and good answers which give a very good view of it and allow for a good decision on the claim. Based on the information gathered from the QA it appears the claim itself was made by Donald Trump, we know that he has a problem with mail in ballots as he often refers to them as being a method of rigging an election, the QA has found that Donald Trump himself however used a mail in absentee ballot to vote. Theres plenty of information from further QA to discover that theres lots of secure safeguards in place to both prevent voter fraud and it also prooves that someone is not possible to vote by mail then in person. For this claim I have therefore refuted it.
speaker: Donald Trump

justification: Each state has their own process for voting  therefore the claim is ref5

British writer and former communist Philip Spratt, wrote in 1939.
Gujarat, though economically advanced, is culturally a backward province… . Bengal in contrast is economically backward but culturally advanced.

claim: Jack Ma said, "2020 is not the year of thinking about your dreams or plans, but just to ensure that you stay alive"

claim: Seating arrangement in Sudarshan 35mm cinema has been rearranged to suit physical distancing norms

justification: Correct

claim: Department of telecom in India has made internet free till May 17, 2020.

The link given in the claim metadata is also fake. The claim has also been externally fact checked as false from PIB Fact Check. Therefore, this claim is refuted.

claim: New York’s Andrew Cuomo and California’s Gavin Newsom, praise Trump amid the pandemic.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: Q3 finds that these comments were taken out of context.

claim: Biden and Pelosi attacked Trump’s pandemic response.

justification:
Q&A 1 says Biden did condemn Trump for hysterical xenophobia and other things in his covid response, Q&A2 shows Pelosi did attack him by tearing up a copy of his speech but this has no evidence of it being related to his covid response.
so only shows Biden attacking him which is only half the claim.

claim: Nigerian Vice President Yemi Osibanjo said "I plead to Nigerians Don’t Retaliate Fulani Herdsmen Killings, Pray For Them Instead; just as we the Federal Executive are praying hard now."
label: Refuted

claim: The COVID-19 pandemic is a cover-up to allow for the deployment of dangerous 5G telecommunications towers.
label: Refuted
justification: The answer and sources show that there are only a few countries with 5G and a lot more countries with covid cases so the claim is refuted.

claim: Retail milk prices have gone up, farmer price pay has dropped

However, the organizations must apply social distance as much as possible, including ending in-person retail.

Q&A 3 points out that kids also die of covid which again is against the claim that they don't.

claim: Keep the room temperature at 30-40 degrees Celsius to prevent COVID-19.

This information is not listed in their recommendations, instead they have listed:
Get vaccinated as soon as it’s your turn and follow local guidance on vaccination.
Keep physical distance of at least 1 metre from others, even if they don’t appear to be sick. Avoid crowds and close contact.
Wear a properly fitted mask when physical distancing is not possible and in poorly ventilated settings.
Clean your hands frequently with alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water.
Cover your mouth and nose with a bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze. Dispose of used tissues immediately and clean hands regularly. 
If you develop symptoms or test positive for COVID-19, self-isolate until you recover.
speaker: Brahmins

John McCain, and myself for that matter myself, would never let thousands of Americans die from a pandemic while in office"
label: Refuted
justification: No evidence found of tweet in a searchable database of all Trump’s tweets.

claim: Africans living in China are being forced to sleep outside in the cold as Chinese nationals blame them for the rising number of new coronavirus cases in the country.

reporting_source: Twitter and other social media Post

Questions 2 and 3 are unrelated to the claim, and the 4th question-answer pair is a poor pair because it only establishes that 2 organisations are not keeping records of deaths of essential workers, but does not establish which organisations are keeping those records.

claim: Joe Biden said that OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) was not enforcing coronavirus guidelines when Donald Trump was US president.

claim: The US media minimized the risk of the new coronavirus from the start,

claim: NY: EXHAUSTED FUNERAL HOME EMPLOYEE CREMATED BY MISTAKE WHILE TAKING A NAP

claim: The coronavirus originated outside China.

claim: In the United States, the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) admitted in federal court that it does not have studies to support the claim that vaccines do not cause autism.

claim: In October 2019, Bill Gates sponsored Event 201, a simulation that estimated 65 million people would be killed by coronavirus.
label: Refuted
justification: The 201 event was an exercise that illustrated areas where public-private partnerships will be necessary during the response to a severe pandemic in order to diminish large-scale economic and societal consequences. It had no association with the COVID-19 pandemic and did not predict 65 million deaths due to the coronavirus. Hence - this claim is refuted.

tests for qualitative detection of nucleic acid from SARS-CoV-2 in upper and lower

Artemisia has been considered as a possible treatment for COVID-19 and should be tested for efficacy and adverse side effects. Artemisia herba-alba has also been found to be useful against COVID-19 (in silico); however, there is insufficient clinical research evidence based on these compounds for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2.

Q&A 3 shows that around the time of the claim the Indian Gov did ask its supreme court for the power to prevent only media from posting updates and news online with out checking facts first.

There is a difference between saying somebody planned something and blaming someone for something.
There is a difference between planning a pandemic and creating a virus. 
The question and answer don't "match". The answer doesn't specifically answer what was asked.
The source given is a fact checking article.

claim: The Treasury expects the UK economy to shrink by 4.9% under a Canada-style deal with the EU.
label: Refuted
justification:
Evidence finds this to be incorrect. The economy would not shrink under a Canada-style deal.

The government’s analysis said that "in all scenarios, the economy would be expected to grow,"  albeit slower than if we had not left the EU.

The 4.9% is estimated from a hypothetical free-trade agreement (FTA) with the EU where we maintained tariff-free access but there were still non-tariff costs (such as regulatory barriers) that would cost the UK between 4.9% and 6.7% of GDP growth after 15 years.

claim: The United States is “actually screening fewer people (for the coronavirus than other countries) because we don't have appropriate testing."

claim: Nigel Farage stated Nearly two-thirds of British businesses do not make a profit of over £10,000 but are subjected to corporation tax.

justification: The claim begins and is phrased as "Nigel Farage stated..." - because of this, the question and answer pairs should therefore be structured in order to verify the authenticity of the alleged quote in the claim. The source document for question 1 lists Nigel Farage as both the leader of the Brexit Party and the first signatory to this Brexit Party "Contract with the people" document. The statement referring to Corporation Tax and most relevant to the claim within the document states - "one million companies - some 66% of the total number - pay less than £10,000. This represents just 6% of Corporation Tax take in 2019; £3.4bn. Total cost £5.1bn per year." It doesn't discuss two thirds of British businesses not making a profit of over £10,000, rather that they propose to Zero rate Corporation Tax for the first £10,000 of pre-tax profits. Also the source document in answer 1 doesn't discuss - "fewer than half of British businesses make a profit of less than £10,000" as referenced in answer 1.

There is also no mention of the public option. Hence, there is not enough evidence.

claim: The "boyfriend loophole" means that "if you commit a serious crime of domestic abuse against your wife, you can't get a gun, but if you do it against your girlfriend, you can.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: Evidence finds that federal law defines domestic violence as the use or attempted use of physical force or the threatened use of a deadly weapon, committed by a current or former spouse, parent, or guardian of the victim; by a person with whom the victim shares a child in common; by a person who is cohabiting with or has cohabited with the victim as a spouse, parent, or guardian; or by a person similarly situated to a spouse, parent, or guardian of the victim. There is no mention of a more casual relationship in federal law. However, states have closed the gaps in federal law pertaining to people who commit misdemeanor crimes of domestic violence by enacting laws that prohibit domestic violence misdemeanors not covered by federal law from buying or possessing guns and/or ammunition. But, multiple states have no such law.
speaker: U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar

claim: Geckos carry pathogenic bacteria in their mouths which are very toxic to humans.

justification: Evidence finds conflicting evidence, where one side showcases that wild-caught geckos may have different types of bacteria in their oral cavities than captive-hatched ones. The bacteria can be potentially dangerous bacteria, protozoa, or, rarely, a pathogenic fungus that can be transmitted to a human via a bite that punctures the skin. There was also a Salmonella outbreak in 16 states that was linked to pet geckos. On the other hand, it is said that geckos are non-toxic, do not bite, and are not known to transmit any kind of infection or disease to humans.
speaker: Fß finest photos

claim: Food stamp participation in America hits 10 year low.

claim: Biden didn’t support more money to build state prisons.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification:
QA shows Biden supported $6 billion but not $10 billion of funding to build state prisons. Claim does not define what ‘more’ is, but clear that Biden supported at least some funding of state prison construction.
NB QA source links to a fact checking article.

claim: County governments have allocated on average 6.7 % of their total budgets to the agriculture sector.

Using the current stats offered as evidence though, without clarification about which fiscal year is referenced, refuted or not enough evidence are the choices.  Refuted chosen as the most likely scenerio.

claim: In Kenya, County Governments have allocated on average 6.7% of their total budgets to the agriculture sector.

claim: In 2018/2019 in Kenya, all county governments allocated at least 20% of their budgets to health.

Confirmed at $434,
774

claim: Companies like Halliburton and Amazon pay nothing in US taxes
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: Evidence has found that both Amazon and Halliburton pay US taxes. However, there is a contradiction where the evidence has found that it's Amazon's second straight year owing no tax: In 2017, Amazon filed for a $137 million refund on $5.6 billion in profit. Hence, conflicting evidence.

claim: President Trump “immediately discontinued” an aid program to Central America which is the cause of surging immigration across the U.S.-Mexico border.
label: Refuted
justification: Answer support a drop in funding but not an immediate discontinuation which makes the further points of the claim invalid however there was an increase in attempted crossings.

reporting_source: Night two of the primary election debates

claim: Many of America's 2.3 million prisoners are incarcerated for nonviolent drug crimes
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: Evidence finds that there are 2,121,600 prisoners in U.S. prisons, not 2.3 million as the claim states. Evidence also finds that even though most Americans assume the figure is about 50%, somewhat fewer than 15% are incarcerated for drug offenses. Drug offenses are far more prevalent in the federal prison system, but that houses only about 10 percent of all prisoners; most incarcerated people are in state prison. Hence, the evidence is conflicting.
speaker: Beto O'Rourke

claim: The price of 2,500 drugs has gone up in double digits under Donald Trump's administration
label: Supported
justification: 2,500 drugs increased in price in 2018 when Trump is the president, according to the Centers for Medicare Services in the United States.

claim: President Donald Trump has thrown 32 million people off their health care that they have.

justification: Not all of the 32million will be taken off their health care

reporting_source: Night two of the primary election debates

claim: The top 1 percent wealthiest control 90 percent of the wealth in the US

claim: Number one reason for why American families go broke is the cost of healthcare
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification:
Q7A 1 shows that contrary to what is claimed medical factors play a much smaller role in causing U.S. bankruptcies than has previously been claimed
Q&A 2 is also contrary to the claim showing that evidence on medical bankruptcy is built on the fallacy that when two things occur together there is necessarily a causal relationship between them. along with Q&A's 4 also not agreeing with the claim
However Q&A 5 shows that 60 percent of bankruptcies are linked to medical bills which conflicts with the other Q&A's so this is problematic for judging the claim.
speaker: Elizabeth Warren

claim: The CEO of McDonald's makes 2,100 times more than "the people slinging hash" at McDonald's
label: Refuted

claim: Rep. Tim Ryan of Ohio said: “The bottom 60 percent of Americans haven’t seen a raise since 1980.”

justification: The source material contains more content but overall it refutes the claim. Answer may be cherrypicked.

claim: The reason that they are separating these little children from their families is that they are using Section 1325 of that act, which criminalizes coming across the border to incarcerate the parents and then separate them. Some of us on this stage have called to end that section, to terminate it, some like Congressman O’Rourke have not.

justification: Evidence shows section 1325 criminalises crossing the border, and that O'Rourke opposed appealing it, but the claim is worded badly and is a copied quote.

claim: "The wealthiest three families now own more wealth than the bottom half of the country."

claim: Sen Cory Booker said when Connecticut enacted a permit-to-purchase gun law, “they saw 40 percent drops in gun violence and 15 percent drops in suicides.”
label: Supported
justification: The evidence supports the fact that once Connecticut enacted a permit-to-purchase gun law, there was a 40 percent drop in gun violence and a 15 percent drop in suicides. Hence, the claim is supported.

claim: About 30% of LGBTQ kids do not go to school because of fear.

claim: Sen. Cory Booker claimed the Iran nuclear deal “pushed back a nuclear breakout 10, 20 years.” during the 2020 U.S presidential debate
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: There is no information as the when the Iran nuclear deal was made. There are conflicting answers regarding the impact.

claim: Sen. Cory Booker claimed private insurance overhead was 15 percent, while Medicare’s was “only at 2 percent.”
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification:
Q&A 4 states that the claim was made by the person as claimed in the claim, 
Q&A 1 states that Medicare's overhead is only 1.3% not 2 as claimed, (0.7%diffrence)
Q&A 3 shows that actually The definitions are incompatible and not reconcilable between the systems. so comparing Medicares overhead cost  to private health cares in this way is incorrect, with Q&A 3 listing good points why these figures are incompatible in the way claim shows.

claim: Purdue Pharma has been able to act with complete impunity and pay no consequences for the opioid crisis. Not a single night in jail.

justification: Purdue Pharma has indeed faced consequences for the opioid crisis.

claim: The bottom 60 percent of US employees haven’t seen a wage raise since 1980.

claim: Former Kenyan election commissioner Roselyn Akombe has died.

claim: A generation ago, 37 cents out of every US food dollar went into a farmer’s pocket. Today, it’s 15 cents.

justification: This claim has conflicting evidence. According to the QA pairs, the claim is correct to state that "37 cents out of every US food dollar went into a farmer's pocket" as a 2015 Congressional Research Service report,  indicates that the farm share was about 37 cents in the 1970-1980 period. However, the claim that "today it's 15 cents" seems to be false, as the actual number is 7.8 cents- which is significantly lower. Therefore, this claim has conflicting evidence.

The answer to question 3 states  - Senate Democratic leader "did call" for a congressional probe. It is not addressed who initiated or began the process. Also there is no reference to the latter part of the claim - "as revenge for losing the 2016 election" in any of  answers.

claim: When the wind stops blowing, that’s the end of your electric (power).
label: Refuted

speaker: Donald Trump

claim: For many, many decades veterans have been trying to get VA Choice. You couldn’t get it. ... Now these great veterans, if there’s a big wait, they go outside, they go to a local doctor. We pay the bills. They get better. Everybody is happy. And we actually save a lot of money, if you can believe it. And I got that approved after 44 years of being unable to get it approved.
label: Refuted
justification: From the evidence, it looks like veteran groups were not happy with Trump's wording of "choice," as they saw the Veteran Choice Program as a "privatization," and they’d been warning for years that it would cost taxpayers more money and deliver worse care for veterans. However, the veterans groups had endorsed the bill, but Trump’s description of it was not what they thought they were there to support. The VA option appears to cost between $13.9 billion and $32.1 billion over five years. However, it is not clear on the comparison between VA Choice and other veteran healthcare providers. But, based on the evidence, it looks like the VA Choice comes out as a much more expensive deal. More so, Donald Trump was not president in 2014; it was Barack Obama.
speaker: Donald Trump

justification: Based on the available data from the QA the figures appears to be slightly off and this makes the claim wrong and so it's refuted. In 2013/14 4,713,662 had health insurance, in 2017/18 it had 7,657,463 and as QA pair 3 calculates this is an increase of nearly 3 million but the initial figure in the claim is much lower than the actual statistics from 2013/14 by 1.7 million so it's not risen quite as much as the claim suggests.

claim: The current Kenyan government has built a standard-gauge railway of 600 kilometres in the last five years.
label: Supported
justification: This claim is suppported. According to the QA pairs, the current Kenyan government have built a standard gauge railway which consists of a modern, efficient transport system that makes travel safe, comfortable and affordable for passengers across the country. The Office of th President of Kenya has stated that amount of track that has so far been laid is 472km. 472km is part of phase 1 of the project, implying there is more track to be laid. However, the claim states that 600km of track has been laid over the past 5 years. In the metadata provided, a spokesperson from the office of SGR stated that "the main line is 472 km and the total track built 607.4 km... the difference is because there are areas on the main line with multiple tracks. These include two main stations and seven intermediate stations." The previously stated number of 472km stated seems to be exclusive to the main train line laid, whilst the figure of 607.4km is conclusive of everything intermediate stations. Therefore, the claim is supported as, despite being 'main track' or not, 607.4km (600 kiometres in the claim) has been laid in Kenya.
speaker: Kenyan Deputy President, William Ruto

claim: Kenya has built a standard-gauge railway of 600 kilometres in the last five years.

justification: Evidence shows that phase 1 of the Standard Gauge Railway from Mombasa to Nairobi has 472 km of track completed rather than the claimed 600 km. Hence, the claim is refuted.

Q&A 3 does say financial aid has increased over recent years which agrees with the claim, but Q&A 3 only shows a figure for what it has increased from in 1991 (22million) not 1994 which is the claim point, so more evidence would be needed for an accurate judgment.

claim: Iraq and Syria have been liberated from ISIS.
label: Refuted
justification:
n other words, declaring ISIS has been “beaten” or “defeated,” as President Trump did in December 2018, is flat-out wrong and would be worthy of Pinocchios.More recently, he has said that the United States has liberated “virtually 100 percent of ISIS in Iraq and Syria” and that the caliphate is “almost knocked out.” These assertions are closer to reality. ISIS can no longer claim it has a territorial caliphate in Iraq and Syria. It no longer controls land or operates a government.

That, however, doesn’t mean it could not resurge, as the president’s aides have made clear. In comparison with the last time the United States withdrew forces, the situation is eerily similar if not arguably worse.
speaker: Donald Trump

claim: Bollywood Singer, Lata Mangeshkar had chosen to stop recording new songs.

label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters was taken out of context. Although she was speaking on the ousting of President Donald Trump, she actually said, "Knock off the first one, and then go after the second one," She did say 'We have the power" when she said, “We have the power. We have the numbers, but we’ve got to understand our power and we’ve got to use our power,”

claim: Women have to be 25 years old, married, have at least one son and one daughter, and have her husband's consent to get a tubal ligation.
label: Refuted
justification: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pair, tubal ligation is a choice made by the woman deciding on getting the treatment. The only requirements to receive this treatment is counselling as it is an irreversible form of contraception. "When appropiate" the patients partner can be counselled too. You do not need to have 2 children, married and 25 to get tubal ligation. Therefore, this claim is refuted.

claim: Mayonnaise containing starch is harmful.

claim: Shops buy apples that are coated with wax.

claim: A video claiming to show “shocking secrets of the food industry” said You can check whether honey has been diluted with sugar syrup by washing it in water to reveal a honeycomb pattern and the honey’s genetic memory.
label: Refuted
justification: The evidence finds that the honeycomb pattern in honey can differ depending on the species of tree it came from. It is even very hard to tell the difference between fake and real honey. Honey also has no genetic memory and is made up of carbohydrates, proteins, amino acids, vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, and other compounds. Hence, this claim is refuted.

claim: IF any Nigerian Bank fails to return your money within 24 hours of a failed online transfer, they will be fined 10,000 naira. The money goes to YOU! All you need to do is report the issue to Central Bank (cpd@cbn.gov.ng) and they will surely take it up.
label: Not Enough Evidence
justification: The 2nd Q&A pair confirms what the claim says about a fine on banks who fail to return customers funds in a set timeframe of a failed transfere, However it points out that the regulation iteelf does not say who receives the fines, so there is no way of knowing if it does go to the customer as is claimed.

claim: Sen. Ted Cruz's 2018 campaign tried to trick elderly Texans with suspicious mailers

Q&A 4 points out that people did think they were designed to trick people though so also confirming what the claim says about tricking elderly people, but not elderly people only so again some cherry picking.

claim: Consuming a wax-coated apple can kill you.

HE MINISTER OF STATE
CONSUMER AFFAIRS, FOOD AND PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION
(SHRI C. R. CHAUDHARY)

(a) : Government has approved creation of a dynamic buffer stock of upto 20 lakh MT of pulses for effective market intervention, to moderate its prices.

(b) : As on 14.03.2018, 13.89 lakh MT of pulses is available in the buffer after disposal of 6.61 lakh MT from a total of 20.50 lakh tonnes of pulses procured for building the buffer under Price Stabilization Fund (PSF). As per the data of Directorate General of Commercial Intelligence and Statistics (DGCI&S), M/o Commerce & Industry, the total imports of pulses by India during 2017-18 (upto January) is 5.33 lakh MT.

(c) : For building the dynamic buffer of upto 20 lakh MT of pulses, 16.71 lakh tonnes was procured domestically.

claim: Garlic can kill brain cancer cells
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification:
This was a laboratory study, and no conclusions about the effects of garlic on human health can be drawn from it.

This study did not look at the effects of eating garlic in people who have glioblastoma; it also did not look at whether eating garlic prevents people developing cancer. In addition, this study did not look at the effects of these garlic compounds on healthy human cells; therefore it is possible that these compounds also kill healthy cells.

Based on this studies findings, we shouldn’t believe that eating garlic will prevent or cure cancer.
speaker: Cure 4 cancer

claim: The Covid-19 spike protein which the Pfizer vaccine causes an immune response against also trains the body to attack syncytin-1, a protein in the placenta, which could lead to infertility in women.
label: Refuted
justification: Someone has claimed that the COVID-19 vaccines are going to cause infertility because of a shared amino acid sequence in the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 and a placental protein, which will make the immune system attack both as it can’t tell the difference. The truth? This sequence is too short for the immune system to meaningfully confuse it with placental proteins. It’s sort of like saying that you are going to be confused with a criminal because you wear a commonly sold red bracelet that was also found on the criminal. It’s not realistic. If this were true, we would also expect COVID-19 to cause early pregnancy loss a significant amount of the time. The evidence available to us does not support that this is the case. There is no reasonable basis to believe that vaccines against COVID-19/SARS-CoV-2 will affect fertility.

label: Refuted
justification: QA pair confirms image is altered/photoshopped.

claim: Kenyans working at Mara North private wildlife park have been made to carry white tourists in sedan chairs depicting modern 'slavery'
label: Refuted
justification: This is a well paid service usually taken up by people with disabilities or mobility issues as mentioned in the QA pairs.

claim: Suicide is the cause of death for around 3,000 people per day.
label: Refuted
justification: Based on numbers in QA pairs the amount confirmed is around 1/3rd less.

claim: Using the air conditioning (AC) in a vehicle consumes more fuel.
label: Supported
justification: Using the AC does consume more fuel, but also it is more fuel efficient than opening windows at high speeds. but this is still confirmed

claim: The BMA advises that without immigrants “many NHS services would struggle to provide effective care”.
label: Supported
justification: According to the evidence, 14% of clinical staff and 26% of doctors are foreign nationals. Hence, the claim is supported.
speaker: Social Media Users

claim: The Wuhan coronavirus is a more virulent version of the normal cold.
label: Supported
justification:
The covid virus is from the same family of viruses as the common cold As is shown in Q&A 1, 
Q&A 4 agrees with claim as it shows the covid virus is more contagious, as well as needing other medications to fight it over the common cold so claim of covid being more virulent is correct.

claim: In the UK in 2020 there were 48,000 illegal immigrants staying in 4/5 star hotels.
label: Refuted
justification: 48,000 is the total number of asylum seekers, only 2,800 were house in temporary accommodation including hotels and there was no confirming what type of hotel.

claim: 5G wrecks immune systems and that is why people in Wuhan are suffering with this illness.
label: Refuted
justification:
Q&A 2 points out that 5g radio waves are non-ionising, meaning they don’t damage cells in the way x-rays, gamma rays and uv does, so unlikely to damage a body's immune system as claimed.
Q&A 1 shows there is no evidence to support the claim either.
With Q&a 2 saying Public Health England has said that there’s no “convincing evidence” that exposure below International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation guidelines can cause adverse health effects. These guidelines go up to 300GHz, whereas the maximum for 5G will probably only be in the tens of GHz.

claim: Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan has slammed the Modi-government for not paying enough attention to Rohingya Muslims.
label: Refuted
justification: Shah Rukh Khan did not slam the Modi government and the news source carrying the news is not reliable.

claim: Drinking one glass of water before bed prevents heart attacks.
label: Supported
justification: According to source provided it is medically proven that drinking water before bed has alot of Health benefits
speaker: Nikkis Weight Loss Support

claim: A no deal Brexit means no more ECJ or ECHR.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: the answers show The UK will continue to be a member of the European Court of Human Rights after Brexit because its jurisdiction has nothing to do with the EU, but the UK would lose access to the european court of justice. so this is conflicting information.

claim: Matt Hancock owns the company responsible for supplying the NHS.
label: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking
justification: it seems as if the SCCL company is owned by the secretary of state which is currently matt hancock, but he personally does not own it, just his position affords him ownership

claim: £1 billion was given to 13 companies for PPE but no PPE has been supplied.
label: Not Enough Evidence
justification: We do not have sufficient evidence to verify if "no PPE has been suppolied".

claim: Mixing one tablespoon of 2% iodine and one cup of baby oil will create a substance that removes body hair.
label: Refuted
justification: Refuted in QA pairs , states has no effect on body hair and someone tried it.
